instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance – this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Fan spin for about 20 seconds. I believe I'm getting all the other vcore rails but noticed 0V @<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> diode there to Ground is 0V. Can I isolate and then run voltage to find the short? I noticed a ton of caps would be possible otherwise?...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> diode there to Ground is 0V"
You are not curious to compare with good board?
i7 CPU is aprox 1 ohm to ground, as normal.

AXG voltage usually appears under high graphics load...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: AHHHH... ok. well chasing down rabbit holes. THis shows USB activity (flashing on usb drive) but can't get a pram reset out of it or chime... No image/backlight. Had the heatsink off would that cause turn off as soon as 20 seconds?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: CPU overheats, put back heatsink.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is .97V
PPCPuVCCIO_SO_REG_R is 1V
Man I'm having a hard time figuring out if those are good enough. No good board for reference

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
When this board really boots, VCORE drops to 0.78V aprox.
Check voltage on output pin of L7510/20.
If you get USB activity, board boots; but VCORE doesn't respect known patron in your case.

Board still turns off in 20s?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
L7510/20 both at 1.12V
Sorry forgot to mention no USB activity detected.
Board does not turn off now that the heatsink is back on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Try each RAM slot separately.
Do you have DDR3 test card?
Also try known good BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Nice! Ram card was doing something to prevent stop progress at least. Switching Ram card out (either slot) I now get USB activity. BIOS Chip was swapped already today.

no chime/display image/backlight. No external display activity detected. Smc reset registers. Cant get it to pram reset.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Given there's USB activity but no sign of boot/chime/POST where would I go next on this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"there's USB activity"
For sure?
Flashing Link LED from USB boot pendrive?

"BIOS Chip was swapped already"
Picked from working board?
Even then, ME region must be cleaned...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Voltage to USB only. NO flashing light to indicate activity.

I did reflash the bios with cleanme no change. WOn't pram reset only SMC. NO chime. Fans start slow and eventually work their way to full high speed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Did you check RAM slots with DDR3 test card?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I didn't have a test card or even know they exited... ordered one and I get all lights both sides for both slots.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: No. <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check <SIGNAL>CPU_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_MEM_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
cpu pwrgd = 1.05V
<SIGNAL>PM_MEM_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 1.5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check MEM/<SIGNAL>CPU_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>MEM_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 1.5V
<SIGNAL>CPU_MEM</SIGNAL> <SIGNAL>RESET_L</SIGNAL> 1.5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Something pulls down <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
If is not PCH, there are many resistors distributing this signal on the board.
Not easy to find a culprit.
Try first removing <CHIP>U2680</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Guessing its the PCH not sending signal...
Tried pulling <CHIP>U2680</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R2689</RESISTOR>/81/83/71/88/80 and <CHIP>U2810</CHIP>. <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> remained low in all cases.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_AXG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You can change it...
